  Subject: [junit] RE: I=
s there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?


  In this discussion, ap=
parently we have been talking about "retrofitting" unit tests for old code =
that never before had them. The notion seems to be that each method in a cl=
ass, or perhaps each public method, should have a unit test.

  I think thi=
s is wrong. I think, as J.B. said, that in such a case you should concentra=
te on testing features, not simply methods.

  I would say that for new cod=
e, where you're writing tests along with your production code, it might mak=
e sense to try for a test per (public) method. But that's because in this c=
ase you have the benefit of thinking about the testing at the time you're w=
riting the code. I think you're more likely to design your code in such a w=
ay as to have this make more sense. (The "testing influences design" notion=
.)

  The problem I see with mindlessly (or even mindfully) writing a test =
for each method, just to satisfy someone's idea that code coverage is good,=
 is that you're likely to (1) invest a lot of (or even a little) time; and =
(2) generate a lot of test code (which will have to be maintained, don't fo=
rget), for what will turn out to be little or no benefit. I would bet that =
the marginal number of bugs found by "complete" per-method tests over a mor=
e sensible per-feature approach, both now and forever in the future, is ver=
y close to zero. At least that's my impression based on my own experiences.=


  More is not always better.

  I would be very curious to know if anyone=
 can report on actual (measured, quantitative) experiences that either supp=
ort or refute this.
